channel.title: Pages on POLS 501: Advanced Political Research Design and Analysis
channel.description: Recent content in Pages on POLS 501: Advanced Political Research Design and Analysis

item.title: Git and GitHub
item.description:
Cloning, Pull Requests, Forking, Pulling, and Pushing See the Happy Git and Github for the useR chapter Fork a repo. Homework Workflow {"x":{"diagram":"sequenceDiagram
 participant org as UW-POLS501/assignment-1
 participant user as student/assignment-1
 participant local as local repository
 org-user: Fork repository
 org-local: Clone repository
 loop Until complete
 local-local: Work and commit
 local-user: Push changes
 end
 user-org: Submit with a pull request
 Note over org,local: Solutions released in UW-POLS501/assignment-1-solutions
 loop Until all corrections made
 local-local: Work and commit
 local-user: Push changes
 end
 user-org: Submit with a pull request"

item.title: Onboarding
item.description: Please complete the following before the first day of class. Sign up for our Slack channel. You should have received an invite. If not email the instructors. Sign up for a GitHub Fill out course survey using the course. The should have received an email with the link. A link is also posted on the Slack channel. Fill out the survey with office hour preferences. See the email sent to the class or the Slack channel for a link.

item.title: References
item.description: Articles and books references in this course. Download these references as bibtex file here. Angrist, Joshua D, and Jörn-Steffen Pischke. 2010. “The Credibility Revolution in Empirical Economics: How Better Research Design Is Taking the Con Out of Econometrics.” Journal of Economic Perspectives 24 (2). American Economic Association: 3–30. doi:10.1257/jep.24.2.3. Bailey, Michael A., Anton Strezhnev, and Erik Voeten. 2016. “Estimating Dynamic State Preferences from United Nations Voting Data.” Journal of Conflict Resolution 61 (2).
